review.title: Community Recovery in Graphs with Locality
review.abstract: Motivated by applications in domains such as social networks and computational biology, we study the problem of community recovery in graphs with locality. In this problem, pairwise noisy measurements of whether two nodes are in the same community or different communities come mainly or exclusively from nearby nodes rather than uniformly sampled between all nodes pairs, as in most existing models. We present an algorithm that runs nearly linearly in the number of measurements and which achieves the information theoretic limit for exact recovery.
histories: Preliminary versions; the proofs of all theorems are deferred to the supplemental materials (this http URL)

sections.heading: 2.3 Haplotype Phasing: A Motivating Application
sections.text: Before proceeding with the presentation of the algorithms, here we describe an application of genome phase formation that motivates this research and shows how it can be modeled as a problem of community restoration using local diagrams. Humans have 23 pairs of homologous chromosomes, one maternal and one paternal. Each pair is identical to the sequences of nucleotides A, G, C, T, with the exception of certain documented positions called single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) or genetic variants. At each of these positions, one of the chromosomes assumes one of A, G, C or T that is identical to the majority of the population (the so-called major allele), while the other chromosome adopts a variant (also referred to as the minor allele). sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: We have presented two efficient algorithms that are theoretically optimal information. Instead of relying on a "global" method that attempts to restore all nodes at once, the proposed algorithms emphasize local subgraphs, whose nodes are well connected to each other, and propagate information about different parts of the diagram. In this way, we are able to use the locality structure in a mathematically feasible manner. This paper leaves numerous directions open for further investigation. First, the current work focuses on the simplest constellation in which only two communities exist. metadata.abstractText: Motivated by applications in domains such as social networks and computational biology, we study the problem of community recovery in graphs with locality. In this problem, pairwise noisy measurements of whether two nodes are in the same community or different communities come mainly or exclusively from nearby nodes rather than uniformly sampled between all node pairs, as in most existing models. We present two algorithms that run nearly linearly in the number of measurements and which achieve the information limits for exact recovery.
